comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Wondering where the "Recreation Ground" was.  What's the building behind?  Church / courthouse to the right?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] from Children's institutions in nineteenth-century Sydney by John Ramsland, 2011, Dictionary of Sydney:
A recreation ground was set up for the boys on Cockatoo Island adjacent to the ship's moorage, and a saltwater tidal baths was erected beside it. Larger pets such as an emu were kept on the fringes of the recreation grounds and smaller pets such as dogs and cockatoos were kept aboard ship to be cared for there.
- www.dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/childrens_institutions_i...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
Although not digitised, the Powerhouse Museum description would indicate their entry is for the same photo -
The boys are shown playing cricket and doing gymastics. An Emu is seated in the middle of the ground.
which would date this photo to 1894, and not long before 14 June -
The donor, Captain Frederick William Neitenstein, superintendent of the Sobraon, states in a letter to the Museum, 14 June 1894, that the photographs P1835:P1854 are "just received from the Government Printer".
- www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=321221

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Great info!  Cockatoo Island it is.  And the other 'Sobraon' photo showing the baths - 

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5474994706/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I can't yet make out exactly where on Cockatoo Island the recreation ground, baths, and these buildings were from GoogleMapsSatellite.   Cockatoo (and emu) expert required!

comment.author: 18901029@N00
comment._content: Based on this photo which I think is the Sobraon, I'd guess that the recreation ground was on the eastern side of the island close to where the turbine hall now stands. This photo is taken from the front of the dockmaster's residence with Long Nose point in the background. The tower on the right was on the original convict built workshops adjacent to Fitzroy Dock and was demolished somewhere around the First World War I think. Another photo of the recreation ground with the emu is at www.cockatooisland.gov.au/assets/content/about/history/hi...

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman] Sadly, we have few photos of the (Charles II - the Sheriff) Cowper's days on the Island. Other members of the family may have some still. But thanks to Don it looks like the mystery is solved. But the idea of emus on Cockatoo Island is fascinating. What historic footnotes yet remain unread?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman] Another of your photos (slightly to the right of the one above) shows the tower seen at right of the top photo with a clock and bell,  which makes sense of this being at the east side of the island.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/donshearman/5475408352/]
